citations.narrative:
The facility uses collars and tags as their form of official identification for dogs over 16 weeks of age. There was at least 1
dog over the age of 16 weeks without an official USDA tag on it's collar. An acceptable form of official identification (listed
below) is necessary for APHIS officials to positively identify animals for inspection and to properly trace their movements.
All live dogs over the age of 16 weeks shall be identified by an official tag affixed to a collar around the animal’s neck, by
a legible tattoo marking approved by the Administrator, or by a microchip placed under the dog’s skin. The licensee must
apply one of these forms of identification to the dog. The licensee must ensure that all dogs have an official form of
identification at all times.
To be corrected by: 17-November-2023

The licensee reused a collar with the official ID number of 24 on a chocolate dachshund that was previousy assigned for a
Cavalier King Charles Spaniel that was sold 2-July-2022. Reusing official identification makes it difficult to properly trace
animal movements and identify which dogs are still at a facility. No tag number shall be used to identify more than one
animal. No number shall be repeated within a 5-year period.
To be corrected by: 28-October-2023

Several inventory records were missing.
**missing the date of birth on the cage card for two litters of puppies currently at the facility
**missing the acquisition date for 2 adult dogs- #31 Cocker Spaniel and #17 Dachshund
**missing the disposition date for 3 chihuahua puppies sold this summer
**missing the date of euthanasia of one Cavalier King Charles Spaniel
**#32 female chihuahua is recorded as #114 on the acquisition form
**#34 male chihuahua is recorded as #102 or #101 on the acquisition form
Acquisition and disposition records of animals must be accurate and kept up to date to allow APHIS officials to track the
animals' movements.
Each dealer shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the acquisition information
concerning each dog purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or
her control, or which is transported, euthanized, sold, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer. The facility must accurately
create and maintain all disposition records when each dog is transported, sold, euthanized or otherwise disposed of.
To be corrected by: 30-October-2023

Male Brown and White Cocker Spaniel, tag #31, was severely matted. Both ears were solid tight matting and no skin
could be observed, several matts were also present on top of the dog head. All four feet had a long, overgrown hair with
matts present between the toes and on top of each foot. There was additional loose matting along the back and belly,
feces were present on the feet hair and the hair below the tail. Additionally the nails were severely overgrown and curled
to the sides. This dog was partially shaved during inspection with just the feet left to do.
Male brown Poodle, tag #15, was severely matted. The haircoat on the dog head was overgrown and hair had to be lifted
to observe the dog's eyes. There were loose matts present around the mouth and chest. Tight matts were present on all
four feet, and between the toes, inner legs of hind feet and lower legs on all four feet. There was feces present in the hair
under the tail. The nails were overgrown and starting to curl to the side
Overgrown and matted hair coats may cause pain and discomfort to the animal as well as increase the chance of skin
conditions to develop. Overgrown nails may also cause pain and discomfort as well as significantly change the gait of the
animal.
The program of veterinary care states that long haired dogs will be groomed once a month and clipped as necessary.
These dogs have not been groomed or clipped in several months. The licensee and facility representative are aware
these dogs are in need of a grooming but have not completed it yet. The licensee must follow their preventative care and
treatment plans to ensure healthy and un-matted hair coats, properly trimmed nails, and clean and healthy eyes, ears,
skin, and teeth. The licensee must have these dogs groomed to remove all matting and ensure they follow their
preventative care and treatment plan.
To be corrected by: 28-October-2023
Chocolate Dachshund, tag #20, had severely overgrown toenails and poor dental health. The front toenails curled to the
side and two toes on each front foot crossed over each other. The upper canine teeth are approximately 50% covered in a
brown organic material, all upper and lower cheek teeth are completely covered in brown organic material. There is hard,
brown/yellow organic material present between each upper incisor tooth. A white, creamy organic material is along the
gum line of all upper cheek teeth and canine teeth. The upper gums were mildly reddened. Poor dental disease may
cause pain and discomfort as well as lead to additional medical issues if left untreated. Overgrown nails may also cause
pain and discomfort as well as significantly change the gait of the animal.
The program of veterinary care states nails will be observed and trimmed monthly as needed or when deemed too long. It
also states teeth will be observed monthly and will call vet if swollen gums and redness occurs. The licensee and facility
representative are aware this dog needs a nail trim and was not aware of the dental disease, but agree the dog needs to
be seen by a veterinarian. The licensee must follow their preventative care and treatment plans to ensure healthy and un-
matted hair coats, properly trimmed nails, and clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth. The licensee must have this
dogs nails trimmed and have the teeth examined by a licensed veterinarian and ensure they follow an appropriate
preventative care and treatment plan.
To be corrected by: 28-October-2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.50(a)(1) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
The facility uses collars and tags as their form of official identification for dogs over 16 weeks of age. There was at least 1 
dog over the age of 16 weeks without an official USDA tag on it's collar. An acceptable form of official identification (listed 
below) is necessary for APHIS officials to positively identify animals for inspection and to properly trace their movements. 
All live dogs over the age of 16 weeks shall be identified by an official tag affixed to a collar around the animal’s neck, by 
a legible tattoo marking approved by the Administrator, or by a microchip placed under the dog’s skin. The licensee must 
apply one of these forms of identification to the dog. The licensee must ensure that all dogs have an official form of 
identification at all times. 
To be corrected by: 17-November-2023 
2.53 
   
Use of tags. 
The licensee reused a collar with the official ID number of 24 on a chocolate dachshund that was previousy assigned for a 
Cavalier King Charles Spaniel that was sold 2-July-2022. Reusing official identification makes it difficult to properly trace 
animal movements and identify which dogs are still at a facility. No tag number shall be used to identify more than one 
animal. No number shall be repeated within a 5-year period. 
To be corrected by: 28-October-2023

Records: Dealers and exhibitors.

**missing the date of birth on the cage card for two litters of puppies currently at the facility 
**missing the acquisition date for 2 adult dogs- #31 Cocker Spaniel and #17 Dachshund 
**missing the disposition date for 3 chihuahua puppies sold this summer 
**missing the date of euthanasia of one Cavalier King Charles Spaniel  
**#32 female chihuahua is recorded as #114 on the acquisition form 
**#34 male chihuahua is recorded as #102 or #101 on the acquisition form 
Acquisition and disposition records of animals must be accurate and kept up to date to allow APHIS officials to track the 
animals' movements. 
Each dealer shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the acquisition information

concerning each dog purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or 
her control, or which is transported, euthanized, sold, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer. The facility must accurately

To be corrected by: 30-October-2023 
3.13(a)(4)  Direct
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
Male Brown and White Cocker Spaniel, tag #31, was severely matted. Both ears were solid tight matting and no skin

Overgrown and matted hair coats may cause pain and discomfort to the animal as well as increase the chance of skin
